captions.text: Remember fast Volvos--

the 850T5, the British Touring
Car Championship?

Well, the new Chinese owned
Volvo does remember, which is

why it's toying with the idea
of a new high performance
sub-brand called Polstar.

And no, it has nothing to do
with pole dancing, and

everything to do with
neck-bending acceleration.
So meet the S60 Polstar.

It's like naming a crack pipe
and watching Wallender.

How many other saloon cars can
you buy with a manual gearbox
and over 500 horsepower from a
transversely mounted V6 engine?

If you tell me there's another
one apart from the Volvo

Polstar, I'll say
you're lying.

This is a loopy car, even
by loopy standards.

At it's heart is a standard
S60T6 motor, but they played
around with it.

New rods, I think the pistons
are the same, standard crank,

but all sorts of other
stuff going on.

A massive Garrett turbo,
working at 1.5 bar.
And they've squeezed--
wait for this--

500 mega horsepower, and 424
foot-pounds of torque from it.

It makes for a rather un-S60
driving experience.

Let me get around this corner,
and then give you an idea of
what we're talking about.

Because this an extremely
exciting car.
That is oversteer.
And now we get going.
It's extraordinary.

We're now doing 125
miles an hour.
Why has Volvo built this car?
It's quite simple.
It's an exercise.

It's a study to see whether
Volvo can get back into the
fast car market.

And we are imploring
them to do so.

Because you remember
the Heritage.

You remember T5, T5R, estate
racing cars, things bouncing
over curbs.
They were great days.

And Volvo sold more cars because
it made fast cars.

Of course, it's snowy and
slushy, and not an ideal way

to drive a car like this, that's
riding on Michelin
Pilot Supersport tires.

What I can tell you about the
car is it's got pretty decent
electric power steering.
Gearbox is a bit notchy.
But you know what?

In this day and age, to be
offered this stick thing here

and those pedals down on the
floor is such a privilege that

I'm not going to complain
about that.
It's agile.

It's got some very expensive
Ohlins dampers that feel quite

sophisticated, in that the car's
got lots of support.
So it's firm.

But it's not too crashy
in terms of ride.
And the performance--

we've got some proper old school
lag going on here.

So not much happens
below about three.

And then at about three and
a half, it just takes off.

And it's very, very
fast indeed.

And it's accompanied by lovely
exciting V6 noise.

The other thing you need
to know about the
Polstar is the price.

There are plans to make, I
think, six of these cars.

And they will be
200,000 pounds.

That's because they're
very rare.

Because they're out there for
specialized Volvo cognoscenti,

that want to own one of these
kind of development models.

But just imagine that this car
was a bit less than the

forthcoming M3, but still
had 500 horsepower.
That would be interesting.

So how do you judge a 200,000
pound limited run concept
super small saloon car?

When you get the best super
small saloon car on the

market, that's made,
unsurprisingly, by a German

company, and you put
them together.

Just to find out how wide
of the mark the
S60 is, if at all.

Perhaps it's unfair comparing
this new Polstar to the
establishment.
But we have to.

Because we have to understand
where it sits in the firmament

of small very fast
saloon cars.

So here we have it, the C63 with
AMG performance pack, 487
horsepower, 442 foot-pounds.

It is, by any stretch,
an animal.

On normal summer tires, on quite
a bit of snow, it's a
bit ridiculous.
But what a great little car.

It does so many things
so well.
The steering is delicious.
The chassis is just right.

It's got a really nice
balance on the road.

It's quite an agile car, and yet
it can be very relaxing.

And if you want to do skiddy
stuff, well this one has the
optional differential.

So it will skid pretty
much all day long,
as you can now see.

Because that's right, we're
still oversteering.
We're still oversteering.
We're still oversteering.
We're still oversteering.
We're still oversteering.
No, we're going straight.

Oh, no we're oversteering
again.
Oversteering again.

Right, we're oversteering
again.

That's what happens when you've
got one of these things

and you drive on
a bit of snow.

This is not a very objective
test today, because it's not
ideal in snow.

And AMG should not be charging
1,600 quid for an optional
differential.
Because this car is 56 basic.

But the one that's
tested, 72 grand.

I suppose it's cheaper
than 200, isn't it?

The question I have to ask
today is, should Volvo be

attempting to even lock horns
with this kind of machine?

Have the Germans, the AMGs, the
RSs from Audi, and the BMW

Ms moved it so far up the table
now, have they moved

into a different territory, one
that Volvo can't possibly
hope to occupy?
No, they haven't.

I just think Volvo needs to
occupy a space a bit below

this, but kind of offer a real
surprise performance package.

And with 500 horsepower, dare
I say it, the Polstar makes

this thing feel a little bit
slow in a straight line.

And rather handily, Volvo has
Robert Dahlgren, ex world

touring car driver on hand
to drive the S60 Polstar.
I'm still in the Mercedes.

The only way to see just how
quick that thing is is to have
a drag race, right?

It's wet and damp and
icy and horrible.

So a standing start is not
fair on the Mercedes.

So we thought we'd do a rolling
start, and just see
how fast this Volvo really is.
Two, one, go.

It just leapt away from
me in second.
Then it leapt away in third.

We're sort of [INAUDIBLE] no,
it's going away from us.
It's still going away from us.
This has 487 horsepower.

The way it went away in third
gear, when he hit third and

the boost came on
was impressive.
That's a very fast car.

This wasn't a test to decide
whether the S60 Polstar is

indeed a better car
than a C63 AMG.

This was a test to discover
whether Volvo is onto

something with this whole
Polstar brand, and whether it

should go after the Germans
at their own game.

Having experienced that blue
thing fully lit in third gear,
the answer is an emphatic yes.

title: Snowdrift: Volvo S60 Polestar (with a bit of C63 AMG). And a drag race. - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.author: Millo And Otis

comments.text:
+Millo And Otis well, honda and mazda might have had performance in mind a 
long while ago, but where is it now? 
volvo's catching up was quite successful though. the 760 turbo, the 850 t5, 
and the pv544 in their time were up there. 
the thing is.... why are you asking questions if you can answer them 
yourself? and then the performance stuff... i, personally, don't care about 
it as long as the car is rwd and has enough torque to drift in the dry. 
can't think of a reason why this isn't a valid approach, and then this 
question arises: why should i have a honda (none of which are rwd except 
for the aforementioned two by the wayand probably some really early ones) 
which is SUPPOSEDLY performance-oriented or a mazda which all look shit 
(expect for the early rx7) and almost exclusively plasticky garbage..
by the way what's that i'm not seeing? it's mazdas before about 2000 or 
so.. they are mostly dead. hondas do hold up a bit better though, but i 
know no old civic owners (most abundant and popular with ricers due to vtec 
unicorns or something) who have had no problems. another funny thing: 2007 
201hp accord.... slower than a 170hp vw tiguan. yeah, they're so sporty 
from the ground up.

comments.text:
+IER InfoEntertainmentReviews it seems that in conditions of lack of 
maintainance the 740 and other rwd volvos outlast the 850s and other fwd 
ones. where i'm from, there's a comparable amount of both, and the time of 
production difference is significant. probably that's because the rwd stuff 
is much simpler and really built to last, while i can't say that about 
later ones. had a 960 (with a 6304; i know it's rwd but it has much in 
common with the next generation) - lots of trouble, tranny almost died, and 
then i blew the engine. 940/740s? not so much. they're idiot-proof. i'm now 
on my 4th, and that's due to seeking ones in a gradually better nick, they 
don't die).

end he clearly stated it was not a "comparison"... It was a performance 
test with an established car brand and series to see what it's capabilites

years for its safety and wanted to test the waters for a performance/speed 
vehicle.

comments.author: tavi921

comments.text:
They do, although not in this form:
http://www.caranddriver.com/reviews/2015-volvo-s60-v60-polestar-first-drive-review

I see the current Polestar as a warmup to the car featured in this video.  
If Volvo can mass-produce and sell the Polestar in this video for anything 
under $75,000 it will be a hit.  If you get a chance to check out a 
Polestar at a dealership or elsewhere, please do.  I drive a 2012 S60 
R-Design.  It's nice but the fit and finish of the 2015 Polestar is much 
better.

comments.author: Jezen Thomas

comments.text:
That price CH quoted 17 months ago was for 1 of 6 "test models." (I read 
somewhere that one went for $300K before it was even built ...)  When the 
s60 Polestar arrives in the US (June '14) and elsewhere around the world, 
isn't it actually a small run production car? I've read that in Australia 
it's to sell for about $99K AUD, equivalent to maybe $95K US. Meanwhile, 
the "polestar tuning" is available on XC60, S60 and V60 - and of course 
they're sending a few blue (or black) Polestar V60s as well.

The line of CH's review that stands out to me is that making some 
performance cars means Volvo "will sell more cars." Not because they'd sell 
a ton of performance cars, mind you, but having those in the showroom means 
some of the gold rubs off on the other models and enhances the marque.﻿

comments.author: DJGrasuXXL

comments.text:
Love the car. S60s are great cars on their own. (I would know, I'm a Volvo 
mechanic) This version is fantastic. The T6 with this much power rivals the 
new drive E engine. Also love Chris Harris and all his videos. One thing 
that I can't help but cringe at, he keeps saying V6. Inline 6! Volvo has 
never made a V6. Sorry, can't help but be anal, I spend all day in S60s, 
XC60s, and XC90s. Volvo makes a 2.5 I5, a 3.0 and 3.2 I6, a 4.0 V8, and now 
a 2.0 I4. Not a V6.﻿

comments.author: rico zavala

comments.text:
Jeremy Clarskon wrote a great article in Top Gear mag January this year, 
that car brands are all suffering from absolute stereotyping and labelling, 
people cannot accept that Skoda are good cars now, he had builders laughing 
at him driving a Volvo 'what you in a Volvo?!' before he stated that Volvos 
are very good cars, and fast. Bmw drivers are wankers and so on. Anyway, 
the days of the 850R are long gone (what a silly car by the way a station 
wagon or saloon with 2.4l and a turbo with a gauge where petrol and temp is 
and about 220-260bhp). Those 850s can do half a million miles if certain 
filters like dpf are changed when they should be. Volvos are pioneers of 
safety, spacious, comfortable, luxurious interiors with world leading 
winter driving (one can be set to turn on every day before you leave your 
house for work so it is all heated up and demisted deiced etc!!!) and have 
top speeds up there with BM and Mercedes, they definitely need to start 
bringing out a 'M', 'AMG' or the like!﻿
